Amys and Amylion For goddes loue in trinyte Al þat ben hend herkeniþ to me, I pray ?ow, par amoure, What sum-tyme fel be?ond þe see [Of] two barons of grete bounte And men of grete honoure; Her faders were barons hende, Lordinges com of grete kynde And pris men in toun and tour; To here of þese children two How þey were in wele and woo Ywys it is grete doloure. In weele and woo how þey gan wynd & how vnkouth þey were of kynd, Þe children bold of chere, And how þey were good & hend And how ?ong þei becom frend In cort þere þey were, And how þey were made kny?t And how þey were trouþ ply?t, Þe children boþ in fere, And in what lond þei were born And what þe childres name worn Herkeneþ and ?e mow here. In Lumbardy, y vnderstond, Whilom bifel in þat lond, In romance as we reede, Two barouns hend wonyd in lond And had two ladyes free to fond, Þat worthy were in wede; Of her hend ladyes two Twoo knaue childre gat þey þoo Þat dou?ty were of dede, And trew weren in al þing, And þerfore Ihesu, heuyn-king, Ful wel quyted her mede. Þe children-is names, as y ?ow hy?t, In ryme y wol rekene ry?t And tel in my talkyng; Boþ þey were getyn in oo ny?t And on oo day born a-ply?t, For soth with-out lesyng; Þat oon baroun son, ywys Was ycleped childe Amys At his cristenyng; Þat oþur was clepyd Amylyoun, Þat was a childe of grete renoun And com of hy?e ofspryng. The children gon þen þryue, Fairer were neuer noon on lyue, Curtaise, hende, and good; When þey were of ?eres fyue, Alle her kyn was of hem blyþ, So mylde þey were of mood; When þey were seuyn ?ere olde, Grete ioy euery man of hem tolde To beholde þat frely foode; When þey were twel ?ere olde, In al þe londe were noon so bolde, So faire of boon and blood. In þat tyme, y vnderstond, A duk wonyd in þat lond, Prys in toun and toure; Frely he let [sende his sonde], After erles, barouns, fre and bond, And ladies bry?t in boure; A ryche fest he wolde make Al for Ihesu Cristes sake Þat is oure sauyoure; Muche folk, as y ?ow saye, He lete after sende þat daye With myrth [and] grete honoure. Thoo barouns twoo, þat y of tolde, And her sones feire and bolde To court þey com ful ?are. When þey were comyn, ?ong and olde, Mony men gan hem byholde Of lordynges þat þere were, Of body how wel þey were py?t, And how feire þey were of sy?t, Of hyde and hew and here; And al þey seide with-out lesse Fairer children þan þey wesse Ne sey þey neuer ?ere. In al þe court was þer no wy?t, Erl, baroun, squyer, ne kny?t, Neither lef ne loothe, So lyche þey were both of sy?t And of waxing, y ?ow ply?t— I tel ?ow for soothe— In al þing þey were so lyche Þer was neither pore ne ryche, Who so beheld hem both, Fader ne moder þat couþ say Ne knew þe hend children tway But by þe coloure of her cloþ. Þat riche douke his fest gan hold Wiþ erles & wiþ barouns bold, As ?e may listen & liþe, Fourtenni?t, as me was told, [With meet and drynke, meryst on mold] To glad þe bernes bliþe; Þer was mirþe & melodye & al maner of menstracie Her craftes for to kiþe; Opon þe fiftenday ful ?are Þai token her leue forto fare & þonked him mani a siþe. Þan þe lordinges schuld forþ wende, Þat riche douke comly of kende Cleped to him þat tide Þo tvay barouns, þat were so hende, & prayd hem al-so his frende In court þai schuld abide, & lete her tvay sones fre In his seruise wiþ him to be, Semly to fare bi his side; & he wald dubbe hem kni?tes to & susten hem for euer mo, As lordinges proude in pride. Þe riche barouns answerd ogain, & her leuedis gan to sain To þat douke ful ?are Þat þai were boþe glad & fain Þat her leuely children tvain In seruise wiþ him ware. Þai ?aue her childer her blisceing & bisou?t Ihesu, heuen king, He schuld scheld hem fro care, & oft þai þonked þe douke þat day & token her leue & went oway, To her owen cuntres þai gun fare. Þus war þo hende childer, ywis, Child Amiloun & child Amis, In court frely to fede, To ride an hunting vnder riis; Ouer al þe lond þan were þai priis & worþliest in wede. So wele þo children loued hem þo, Nas neuer children loued hem so, Noiþer in word no in dede; Bitvix hem tvai, of blod & bon, Trewer loue nas neuer non, In gest as so we rede. On a day þe childer war & wi?t Treweþes to-gider þai gun pli?t, While þai mi?t liue & stond Þat boþe bi day & bi ni?t, In wele & wo, in wrong & ri?t, Þat þai schuld frely fond To hold to-gider at eueri nede, In word, in werk, in wille, in dede, Where þat þai were in lond, Fro þat day forward neuer mo Failen oþer for wele no wo: Þer-to þai held vp her hond. Þus in gest as ?e may here, Þo hende childer in cuntre were, Wiþ þat douke for to abide; Þe douke was bliþe & glad of chere, Þai were him boþe leue & dere, Semly to fare bi his side. Þo þai were fiften winter old, He dubbed boþe þo bernes bold To kni?tes in þat tide, & fond hem al þat hem was nede, Hors & wepen & worþly wede, As princes prout in pride. Þat riche douke, he loued hem so, Al þat þai wald he fond hem þo, Boþe stedes white & broun, Þat in what stede þai gun go, Alle þe lond spac of hem þo, Boþe in tour & toun; In to what stede þat þai went, To iustes oþer to turnament, Sir Amis & sir Amiloun, For douhtiest in eueri dede, Wiþ scheld & spere to ride on stede, Þai gat hem gret renoun. Þat riche douke hadde of hem pris, For þat þai were so war & wiis & holden of gret bounte. Sir Amiloun and sir Amis, He sett hem boþe in gret office, In his court for to be; Sir Amis, as ?e may here, He made his chef botelere, [For he was hend and fre,] & sir Amiloun of hem alle He made chef steward in halle, To di?t al his meine. In to her seruise when þai were brou?t, To geten hem los þam spared nou?t, Wel hendeliche þai bigan; Wiþ riche & pouer so wele þai wrou?t, Al þat hem sei?e wiþ word & þou?t, Hem loued mani a man; For þai were so bliþe of chere, Ouer al þe lond fer & nere Þe los of loue þai wan, & þe riche douke, wiþ-outen les, Of alle þe men þat oliue wes Mest he loued hem þan. Þan hadde þe douke, ich vnderstond, A chef steward of alle his lond, A douhti kni?t at crie, Þat euer he proued wiþ niþe & ond For to haue brou?t hem boþe to schond Wiþ gile & trecherie. For þai were so gode & hende, & for þe douke was so wele her frende, He hadde þer-of gret envie; To þe douke wiþ wordes grame Euer he proued to don hem schame Wiþ wel gret felonie. So wiþ-in þo ?eres to A messanger þer com þo To sir Amiloun, hende on hond, & seyd hou deþ hadde fet him fro His fader & his moder al-so Þurch þe grace of godes sond. Þan was þat kni?t a careful man, To þat douke he went him þan & dede him to vnderstond His fader & his moder hende War ded, & he most hom wende, For to resaiue his lond. Þat riche douke, comly of kende, Answerd o?ain wiþ wordes hende & seyd, “So god me spede, Sir Amiloun, now þou schalt wende Me nas neuer so wo for frende Þat of mi court out ?ede. Ac ?if euer it bifalle so Þat þou art in wer & wo & of min help hast nede, Saueliche com or send þi sond, & wiþ al mi powere of mi lond Y schal wreke þe of þat dede. Þan was sir Amiloun ferli wo For to wende sir Amis fro, On him was al his þou?t. To a gold-smitþe he gan go & lete make gold coupes to, For þrehundred pounde he hem bou?t, Þat boþe were of o wi?t, & boþe of o michel, ypli?t; Ful richeliche þai were wrou?t, & boþe þai weren as liche, ywis, As was Sir Amiloun & sir Amis, Þer no failed ri?t nou?t. When þat sir Amiloun was al ?are, He tok his leue for to fare, To wende in his iorne. Sir Amis was so ful of care, For sorwe & wo & sikeing sare Al-mest swoned þat fre. To þe douke he went wiþ dreri mode & praid him fair, þer he stode, & seyd, “Sir, par charite, ?if me leue to wende þe fro, Bot ?if y may wiþ mi broþer go, Mine hert, it brekeþ of þre!” Þat riche douke, comly of kende, Answerd o?ain wiþ wordes hende & seyd wiþ-outen delay, “Sir Amis, mi gode frende, Wold ?e boþe now fro me wende? Certes,” he seyd, “nay! Were ?e boþe went me fro, Þan schuld me waken al mi wo, Mi ioie were went oway. Þi broþer schal in to his cuntre; Wende wiþ him in his iurne & com o?ain þis day!” When þai were redi forto ride, Þo bold bernes for to abide Busked hem redy boun. Hende, herkeneþ! Is nou?t to hide, So douhti kni?tes, in þat tide Þat ferd out of þat toun, Al þat day as þai rade Gret morning boþe þai made, Sir Amis & Amiloun, & when þai schuld wende otvain, Wel fair to-gider opon a plain Of hors þai li?t adoun. When þai were boþe a-fot li?t, Sir Amiloun, þat hendi kni?t, Was ri?t-wise man of rede & seyd to sir Amis ful ri?t, “Broþer as we er trewþe-pli?t Boþe wiþ word & dede, Fro þis day forward neuer mo To faily oþer for wele no wo, To help him at his nede, Broþer, be now trewe to me, & y schal ben as trewe to þe, Also god me spede! Ac broþer, ich warn þe biforn, For his loue, þat bar þe croun of þorn To saue al man-kende, Be nou?t o?ain þi lord forsworn, & ?if þou dost, þou art forlorn Euer more wiþ-outen ende. Bot euer do trewþe & no tresoun & þenk on me, sir Amiloun, Now we asondri schal wende. &, broþer, ?ete y þe forbede Þe fals steward felawerede, Certes, he wil þe schende!” As þai stode so, þo breþeren bold, [Sir Amiloun] drou? forþ tvay coupes of gold, Ware liche in al þing, & bad sir Amis þat he schold Chese wheþer he haue wold, Wiþ-outen more duelling, & seyd to him, “Mi leue broþer, Kepe þou þat on & y þat oþer, For godes loue, heuen king; Lete neuer þis coupe fro þe, Bot loke her-on & þenk on me, It tokneþ our parting.” Gret sorwe þai made at her parting & kisten hem wiþ ei?en wepeing, Þo kni?tes hende & fre. Aiþer bitau?t oþer heuen king, & on her stedes þai gun spring & went in her iurne. Sir Amiloun went hom to his lond & sesed it al in to his hond, Þat his elders hadde be, & spoused a leuedy bri?t in bour & brou?t hir hom wiþ gret honour & miche solempnete. Lete we sir Amiloun stille be Wiþ his wiif in his cuntre— God leue hem wele to fare— & of sir Amis telle we; When he com hom to court o?e, Ful bliþe of him þai ware; For þat he was so hende & gode, Men blisced him, boþe bon & blod, Þat euer him gat & bare, Saue þe steward of þat lond, Euer he proued wiþ niþe & ond To bring him in-to care. Þan on a day bifel it so Wiþ þe steward he met þo, Ful fair he gret þat fre. “Sir Amis,” he seyd, “þe is ful wo For þat þi broþer is went þe fro, &, certes, so is me. Ac of his wendeing haue þou no care, ?if þou wilt leue opon mi lare, & lete þi morning be, & þou wil be to me kende, Y schal þe be a better frende Þan euer ?ete was he. “Sir Amis,” he seyd, “do bi mi red, & swere ous boþe broþerhed & pli?t we our trewþes to; Be trewe to me in word & dede, & y schal, so god me spede, Be trewe to þe al so.” Sir Amis answerd, “Mi treuþe y pli?t To sir Amiloun, þe gentil kni?t, Þei he be went me fro. Whiles þat y may gon & speke, Y no schal neuer mi treuþe breke, Noiþer for wele no wo. For bi þe treuþe þat god me sende, Ichaue him founde so gode & kende, Seþþen þat y first him knewe, For ones y pli?t him treuþe, þat hende, Where so he in warld wende, Y schal be to him trewe; & ?if y were now forsworn & breke mi treuþe, y were forlorn, Wel sore it schuld me rewe. Gete me frendes whare y may, Y no schal neuer bi ni?t no day Chaunge him for no newe.” Þe steward þan was egre of mode, Al-mest for wretþe he wex ner wode & seyd, wiþ-outen delay, & swore bi him þat dyed on rode: “Þou traitour, vnkinde blod, Þou schalt abigge þis nay. Y warn þe wele,” he seyd þan, “Þat y schal be þi strong foman Euer after þis day!” Sir Amis answerd þo, “Sir, þer-of ?iue y nou?t a slo; Do al þat þou may!” Al þus þe wrake gan biginne, & wiþ wretþe þai went atvinne, Þo bold bernes to. Þe steward nold neuer blinne To schende þat douhti kni?t of kinne, Euer he proued þo. Þus in court to-gider þai were Wiþ wretþe & wiþ loureand chere Wele half a ?ere & mo, & afterward opon a while Þe steward wiþ tresoun & gile Wrou?t him ful michel wo. So in a time, as we tel in gest, Þe riche douke lete make a fest Semly in somers tide; Þer was mani a gentil gest Wiþ mete & drink ful onest To serui by ich a side. Miche semly folk was samned þare, Erls, barouns, lasse & mare, & leuedis proude in pride. More ioie no mi?t be non Þan þer was in þat worþly won, Wiþ blisse in borwe to bide. Þat riche douke, þat y of told, He hadde a douhter fair & bold, Curteise, hende & fre. When sche was fiften winter old, In al þat lond nas þer non yhold So semly on to se, For sche was gentil & auenaunt, Hir name was cleped Belisaunt, As ?e may liþe at me. Wiþ leuedis & maidens bri?t in bour Kept sche was wiþ honour & gret solempnite. Þat fest lasted fourten ni?t Of barouns & of birddes bri?t & lordinges mani & fale. Þer was mani a gentil kni?t & mani a seriaunt, wise & wi?t, To serue þo hende in [hale]. Þan was þe boteler, sir Amis, Ouer al yholden flour & priis, Trewely to telle in tale, & douhtiest in eueri dede & worþliest in ich a wede & semliest in sale. Þan þe lordinges schulden al gon & wende out of þat worþli won, In boke as so we rede, Þat miri maide gan aske anon Of her maidens euerichon & seyd, “So god ?ou spede, Who was hold þe dou?tiest kni?t & semlyest in ich a si?t & worþliest in wede, & who was þe fairest man Þat was yholden in lond þan, & dou?tiest of dede?” Her maidens gan answere ogain & seyd, “Madame, we schul þe sain Þat soþe bi Seyn Sauour: Of erls, barouns, kni?t & swain Þe fairest man & mest of main & man of mest honour, It is sir Amis, þe kinges boteler; In al þis warld nis his per, Noiþer in toun no tour; He is douhtiest in dede & worþliest in eueri wede & chosen for priis & flour.” Belisaunt, þat birdde bri?t, When þai hadde þus seyd, ypli?t, As ?e may listen & liþe, On sir Amis, þat gentil kni?t, Ywis, hir loue was al ali?t, Þat no man mi?t it kiþe. Wher þat sche sei?e him ride or go, Hir þou?t hir hert brac atvo, Þat hye no spac nou?t wiþ þat bliþe; For hye no mi?t ni?t no day Speke wiþ him, þat fair may, Sche wepe wel mani a siþe. Þus þat miri maiden ?ing Lay in care & loue-morning Boþe bi ni?t & day; As y ?ou tel in mi talking, For sorwe sche spac wiþ him no þing, Sike in bed sche lay. Hir moder come to hir þo & gan to frain hir of hir wo, Help hir ?if hye may; & sche answerd wiþ-outen wrong, Hir pines were so hard & strong, Sche wald be loken in clay. Þat riche douke in o morning & wiþ him mani a gret lording, As prince prout in pride, Þai di?t him wiþ-outen dueling, For to wende on dere-hunting, & busked hem for to ride. When þe lordinges euerichon Were went out of þat worþli won— In herd is nou?t to hide— Sir Amis, wiþ-outen les, For a malady þat on him wes, At hom he gan to abide. When þo lordinges were out ywent Wiþ her men hende & bowes bent, To hunte on holtes hare, Þan sir Amis, verrament, He bileft at hom in present, To kepe al þat þer ware. Þat hendi kni?t biþou?t him þo, In-to þe gardin he wold go, For to solas him þare. Vnder a bou? as he gan bide, To here þe foules song þat tide, Him þou?t a blisseful fare. Now, hende, herkeneþ, & ?e may here Hou þat þe doukes douhter dere Sike in hir bed lay. Hir moder com wiþ diolful chere & al þe leuedis þat þer were, For to solas þat may: “Arise vp,” sche seyd, “douhter min, & go play þe in to þe gardin Þis semly somers day; Þer may þou here þe foules song Wiþ ioie & miche blis among, Þi care schal wende oway.” Vp hir ros þat swete wi?t, In-to þe gardine sche went ful ri?t Wiþ maidens hende & fre. Þe somers day was fair & bri?t, Þe sonne him schon þurch lem of li?t, Þat semly was on to se. Sche herd þe foules gret & smale, Þe swete note of þe ni?tingale Ful mirily sing on tre; Ac hir hert was so hard ibrou?t, On loue-longing was al hir þou?t, No mi?t hir gamen no gle. & so þat mirie may wiþ pride Went in-to þe orchard þat tide, To slake hir of hir care. Þan sey?e sche sir Amis biside, Vnder a bou? he gan abide, To here þo mirþes mare. Þan was sche boþe glad & bliþe, Hir ioie couþe sche noman kiþe, When þat sche sei?e him þare; & þou?t sche wold for noman wond Þat sche no wold to him fond & tel him of hir fare. Þan was þat may so bliþe o mode, When sche sei?e were he stode, To him sche went, þat swete, & þou?t, for alle þis warldes gode, Bot ?if hye spac þat frely fode, Þat time no wold sche lete. & as tite as þat gentil kni?t Sei?e þat bird in bour so bri?t Com wiþ him for to mete, O?aines hir he gan wende, Wiþ worde boþe fre & hende Ful fair he gan hir grete. Þat mirie maiden sone anon Bad hir maidens fram hir gon & wiþ-drawe hem oway; & when þai were to-gider al-on, To sir Amis sche made hir mon & seyd opon hir play, “Sir kni?t, on þe mine hert is brou?t, Þe to loue is al mi þou?t Boþe bi ni?t & day; Þat bot þou wolt mi leman be, Ywis, min hert brekeþ a þre, No lenger libben y no may. “Þou art,” sche seyd, “a gentil kni?t, & icham a bird in bour bri?t, Of wel hei?e kin ycorn, & boþe bi day & bi ni?t Mine hert so hard is on þe li?t, Mi ioie is al forlorn; Pli?t me þi trewþe þou schalt be trewe & chaunge me for no newe Þat in þis world is born, & y pli?t þe mi treuþe al-so, Til god & deþ dele ous ato, Y schal neuer be forsworn.” Þat hende kni?t stille he stode & al for þou?t chaunged his mode & seyd wiþ hert fre, “Madame, for him þat dyed on rode, Astow art comen of gentil blode & air of þis lond schal be, Biþenke þe of þi michel honour; Kinges sones & emperour Nar non to gode to þe; Certes, þan were it michel vnri?t, Þi loue to lain opon a kni?t Þat naþ noiþer lond no fe. “& ?if we schuld þat game biginne, & ani wi?t of al þi kinne Mi?t it vndergo, Al our ioie & worldes winne We schuld lese, & for þat sinne Wretþi god þer-to. & y dede mi lord þis deshonour, Þan were ich an iuel traitour; Ywis, it may nou?t be so. Leue madame, do bi mi red & þenk what wil com of þis dede: Certes, no þing bot wo.” Þat mirie maiden of gret renoun Answerd, “Sir kni?t, þou nast no croun; For god þat bou?t þe dere, Wheþer artow prest oþer persoun, Oþer þou art monk oþer canoun, Þat prechest me þus here? Þou no schust haue ben no kni?t, To gon among maidens bri?t, Þou schust haue ben a frere! He þat lerd þe þus to preche, Þe deuel of helle ichim biteche, Mi broþer þei he were! “Ac,” sche seyd, “bi him þat ous wrou?t, Al þi precheing helpeþ nou?t, No stond þou neuer so long. Bot ?if þou wilt graunt me mi þou?t, Mi loue schal be ful dere abou?t Wiþ pines hard & strong; Mi kerchef & mi cloþes anon Y schal torende doun ichon & say wiþ michel wrong, Wiþ strengþe þou hast me todrawe; Ytake þou schalt be þurch londes lawe & dempt hei?e to hong!” Þan stode þat hendy kni?t ful stille, & in his hert him liked ille, No word no spac he þo; He þou?t, “Bot y graunt hir wille, Wiþ hir speche sche wil me spille, Er þan y passe hir fro; & ?if y do mi lord þis wrong, Wiþ wilde hors & wiþ strong Y schal be drawe al-so.” Loþ him was þat dede to don, & wele loþer his liif forgon; Was him neuer so wo. & þan he þou?t, wiþ-outen lesing, Better were to graunt hir asking Þan his liif for to spille. Þan seyd he to þat maiden ?ing, “For godes loue, heuen king, Vnderstond to mi skille. Astow art maiden gode & trewe Biþenk hou oft rape wil rewe & turn to grame wel grille, & abide we al þis seuenni?t, As icham trewe gentil kni?t, Y schal graunt þe þi wille.” Þan answerd þat bird bri?t & swore, “Bi Ihesu, ful of mi?t, Þou scapest nou?t so oway. Þi treuþe anon þou schalt me pli?t, Astow art trewe gentil kni?t, Þou schalt hold þat day.” He graunted hir hir wil þo, & pli?t hem trewþes boþe to, & seþþen kist þo tvai. Into hir chaumber sche went ogain, Þan was sche so glad & fain, Hir ioie sche couþe no man sai. Sir Amis þan wiþ-outen duelling, For to kepe his lordes coming, Into halle he went anon. When þai were comen fram dere-hunting & wiþ him mani an hei?e lording In to þat worþly won, After his douhter he asked swiþe; Men seyd þat sche was glad & bliþe, Hir care was al agon. To eten in halle þai brou?t þat may, Ful bliþe & glad þai were þat day & þonked god ichon. When þe lordinges, wiþ-outen les, Hendelich were brou?t on des Wiþ leuedis bri?t & swete, As princes þat were proude in pres, Ful richeliche serued he wes Wiþ menske & mirþe to mete. When þat maiden þat y of told, Among þe birdes þat were bold, Þer sche sat in her sete, On sir Amis, þat gentil kni?t, An hundred time sche cast hir si?t, For no þing wald sche lete. On sir Amis, þat kni?t hendy, Euer more sche cast hir ey?e, For no þing wold sche spare. Þe steward ful of felonie, Wel fast he gan hem aspie, Til he wist of her fare, & bi her si?t he parceiued þo Þat gret loue was bi-tvix hem to, & was agreued ful sare, & þou?t he schuld in a while Boþe wiþ tresoun & wiþ gile Bring hem in to care. Þus, ywis, þat miri may Ete in halle wiþ gamen & play Wele four days oþer fiue, Þat euer when sche sir Amis say, Al hir care was went oway, Wele was hir o liue. Wher þat he sat or stode, Sche biheld opon þat frely fode, No stint sche for no striue; & þe steward for wretþe sake Brou?t hem boþe in ten & wrake, Wel iuel mot he þriue. Þat riche douke opon a day On dere-hunting went him to play, & wiþ him wel mani a man; & Belisaunt, þat miri may, To chaumber þer sir Amis lay, Sche went, as sche wele kan; & þe steward, wiþ-outen les, In a chaumber bisiden he wes & sei?e þe maiden þan In-to chaumber hou sche gan glide; For to aspie hem boþe þat tide, After swiþe he ran. When þat may com in-to þat won, Sche fond sir Amis þer al-on, “Hail,” sche seyd, þat leuedi bri?t, “Sir Amis,” sche sayd anon, “Þis day a seuenni?t it is gon, Þat trewþe we ous pli?t. Þerfore icham comen to þe, To wite, astow art hende & fre & holden a gentil kni?t, Wheþer wiltow me forsake Or þou wilt trewely to me take & hold as þou bihi?t?” “Madame,” seyd þe kni?t ogain, “Y wold þe spouse now ful fain & hold þe to mi wiue; Ac ?if þi fader herd it sain Þat ich hadde his douhter forlain, Of lond he wald me driue. Ac ?if ich were king of þis lond & hadde more gode in min hond Þan oþer kinges fiue, Wel fain y wald spouse þe þan; Ac, certes, icham a pouer man, Wel wo is me o liue!” “Sir kni?t,” seyd þat maiden kinde, “For loue of Seyn Tomas of Ynde, Whi seystow euer nay? No be þou neuer so pouer of kinde, Riches anou? y may þe finde Boþe bi ni?t & day.” Þat hende kni?t biþou?t him þan & in his armes he hir nam & kist þat miri may; & so þai plaid in word & dede, Þat he wan hir maidenhede, Er þat [she] went oway. & euer þat steward gan abide Al-on vnder þat chaumber side, Hem for to here. In at an hole, was nou?t to wide, He sei?e hem boþe in þat tide Hou þai seten yfere. & when he sey?e hem boþe wiþ si?t, Sir Amis & þat bird bri?t, Þe doukes douhter dere, Ful wroþ he was & egre of mode, & went oway, as he were wode, Her conseil to vnskere. When þe douke come in to þat won Þe steward o?ain him gan gon, Her conseyl forto vnwrain, “Mi lord, þe douke,” he seyd anon, “Of þine harm, bi Seyn Jon, Ichil þe warn ful fain; In þi court þou hast a þef, Þat haþ don min hert gref, Schame it is to sain, For, certes, he is a traitour strong, When he wiþ tresoun & wiþ wrong Þi douhter haþ forlain!” Þe riche douke gan sore agrame: “Who haþ,” he seyd, “don me þat schame? Tel me, y þe pray!” “Sir,” seyd þe steward, “bi Seyn Jame, Ful wele y can þe tel his name, Þou do him hong þis day; It is þi boteler, sir Amis, Euer he haþ ben traitour, ywis, He haþ forlain þat may. Y sei?e it me self, for soþe, & wil aproue biforn hem boþe, Þat þai can nou?t say nay!” Þan was þe douke egre of mode, He ran to halle, as he were wode, For no þing he nold abide. Wiþ a fauchoun scharp & gode He smot to sir Amis þer he stode, & failed of him biside. In-to a chaumber sir Amis ran þo & schet þe dore bi-tven hem to For drede his heued to hide. Þe douke strok after swiche a dent Þat þurch þe dore þat fauchon went, So egre he was þat tide. Al þat euer about him stode, Bisou?t þe douke to slake his mode, Boþe erl, baroun & swain; & he swore bi him þat dyed on rode He nold for al þis worldes gode Bot þat traitour were slain. “Ich haue him don gret honour, & he haþ as a vile traitour Mi douhter forlain; Y nold for al þis worldes won Bot y mi?t þe traitour slon Wiþ min hondes tvain.” “Sir,” seyd sir Amis anon, “Lete þi wretþe first ouergon, Y pray þe, par charite! & ?if þou may proue, bi Sein Jon, Þat ichaue swiche a dede don, Do me to hong on tre! Ac ?if ani wiþ gret wrong Haþ lowe on ous þat lesing strong, What bern þat he be, He lei?þ on ous, wiþ-outen fail, Ichil aproue it in bataile, To make ous quite & fre.” “?a,” seyd þe douke, “wiltow so, Darstow in to bataile go, Al quite & skere ?ou make?” “?a, certes, sir!” he seyd þo, “& here mi gloue y ?iue þer to, He lei?e on ous wiþ wrake.” Þe steward stirt to him þan & seyd, “Traitour, fals man, Ataint þou schalt be take; Y sei?e it me self þis ich day, Where þat sche in þi chaumber lay, ?our noiþer it may forsake!” Þus þe steward euer gan say, & euer sir Amis seyd, “Nay, Ywis, it nas nou?t so!” Þan dede þe douke com forþ þat may, & þe steward wiþstode al way & vouwed þe dede þo. Þe maiden wepe, hir hondes wrong, & euer swore hir moder among, “Certain, it was nou?t so!” Þan seyd þe douke, “Wiþ-outen fail, It schal be proued in batail & sen bitven hem to. Þan was atvix hem take þe fi?t & sett þe day a fourtenni?t, Þat mani man schuld it sen. Þe steward was michel of mi?t, In al þe court was þer no wi?t, Sir Amis borwe durst ben. Bot for þe steward was so strong, Borwes anowe he fond among, Tventi al bidene. Þan seyd þai alle wiþ resoun, Sir Amis schuld ben in prisoun, For he no schuld nowhar flen. Þan answerd þat maiden bri?t & swore bi Ihesu, ful of mi?t, Þat were michel wrong, “Takeþ mi bodi for þat kni?t, Til þat his day com of fi?t, & put me in prisoun strong. ?if þat þe kni?t wil flen oway & dar nou?t holden vp his day, Bataile of him to fong, Do me þan londes lawe For his loue to be todrawe & hei?e on galwes hong.” Hir moder seyd wiþ wordes bold Þat wiþ gode wil als sche wold Ben his borwe al-so, His day of bataile vp to hold, Þat he as gode kni?t schold Fi?t o?ain his fo. Þus þo leuedis fair & bri?t Boden for þat gentil kni?t To lain her bodis to. Þan seyd þe lordinges euerichon, Þat oþer borwes wold þai non, Bot graunt it schuld be so. When þai had don, as y ?ou say, & borwes founde wiþ-outen delay, & graunted al þat þer ware, Sir Amis sorwed ni?t & day, Al his ioie was went oway, & comen was al his care, For þat þe steward was so strong & hadde þe ri?t & he þe wrong Of þat he opon him bare. Of his liif ?af he nou?t, Bot of þe maiden so michel he þou?t, Mi?t noman morn mare. For he þou?t þat he most nede, Ar þat he to bataile ?ede, Swere an oþ biforn, Þat al so god schuld him spede As he was giltles of þat dede, Þat þer was on him born; & þan þou?t he, wiþ-outen wrong, He hadde leuer to ben anhong Þan to be forsworn. Ac oft he bisou?t Ihesu þo, He schuld saue hem boþe to, Þat þai ner nou?t forlorn. So it bifel opon a day He mett þe leuedi & þat may Vnder an orchard side. “Sir Amis,” þe leuedy gan say, “Whi mornestow so wiþ-outen play? Tel me þat soþe þis tide. No drede þe nou?t,” sche seyd þan, “For to fi?t wiþ þi foman, Wheþer þou wilt go or ride, So richeliche y schal þe schrede, Þarf þe neuer haue of him drede, Þi bataile to abide.” “Madame,” seyd þat gentil kni?t, “For Ihesus loue, ful of mi?t, Be nou?t [wroþ] for þis dede. Ich haue þat wrong & he þe ri?t, Þerfore icham aferd to fi?t, Al so god me spede, For y mot swere, wiþ-outen faile, Al so god me spede in bataile, His speche is falshede, & ?if y swere, icham forsworn, Þan liif & soule icham forlorn; Certes, y can no rede!” Þan seyd þat leuedi in a while, “No mai þer go no noþer gile To bring þat traitour doun?” “?is, dame,” he seyd, “bi Seyn Gile! Her woneþ hennes mani a mile Mi broþer, sir Amiloun, & ?if y dorst to him gon, Y dorst wele swere bi Seyn Jon, So trewe is þat baroun, His owhen liif to lese to mede, He wold help me at þis nede, To fi?t wiþ þat feloun.” “Sir Amis,” þe leuedi gan to say, “Take leue to morwe at day & wende in þi iurne. Y schal say þou schalt in þi way Hom in to þine owhen cuntray, Þi fader, þi moder to se; & when þou comes to þi broþer ri?t, Pray him, as he is hendi kni?t & of gret bounte, Þat he þe batail for ous fong O?ain þe steward þat wiþ wrong Wil stroie ous alle þre.” A morwe sir Amis made him ?are & toke his leue for to fare & went in his iurnay. For noþing nold he spare, He priked þe stede þat him bare Boþe ni?t & day. So long he priked wiþ-outen abod Þe stede þat he on rode In a fer cuntray Was ouercomen & fel doun ded; Þo couþe he no better red, His song was, “Waileway!” & when it was bifallen so, Nedes a-fot he most go, Ful careful was þat kni?t. He stiked vp his lappes þo, In his way he gan to go, To hold þat he bihi?t; & al þat day so long he ran, In to a wilde forest he cam Bitven þe day & þe ni?t. So strong slepe ?ede him on, To win al þis warldes won, No ferþer he no mi?t. Þe kni?t, þat was so hende & fre, Wel fair he layd him vnder a tre & fel in slepe þat tide. Al þat ni?t stille lay he, Til a-morwe men mi?t yse Þe day bi ich a side. Þan was his broþer, sir Amiloun, Holden a lord of gret renoun Ouer al þat cuntre wide, & woned fro þennes þat he lay Bot half a iorne of a day, Noiþer to go no ride. As sir Amiloun, þat hendi kni?t, In his slepe he lay þat ni?t, In sweuen he mett anon Þat he sei?e sir Amis bi si?t, His broþer, þat was treweþe-pli?t, Bilapped among his fon; Þurch a bere wilde & wode & oþer bestes, þat bi him stode, Bisett he was to slon; & he alon among hem stode As a man þat couþe no gode; Wel wo was him bigon. When sir Amiloun was awake, Gret sorwe he gan for him make & told his wiif ful ?are Hou him þou?t he sei?e bestes blake About his broþer wiþ wrake To sle wiþ sorwe & care. “Certes,” he seyd, “wiþ sum wrong He is in peril gret & strong, Of blis he is ful bare.” & þan seyd he, “For soþe ywis, Y no schal neuer haue ioie no blis, Til y wite hou he fare.” As swiþe he stirt vp in þat tide, Þer nold he no leng abide, Bot di?t him forþ anon, & al his meine bi ich a side Busked hem redi to ride, Wiþ her lord for to gon; & he bad al þat þer wes, For godes loue held hem stille in pes, He bad hem so ich-chon, & swore bi him þat schop man-kende, Þer schuld no man wiþ him wende, Bot himself al-on. Ful richeliche he gan him schrede & lepe astite opon his stede, For noþing he nold abide. Al his folk he gan forbede Þat non so hardi were of dede, After him noiþer go no ride. So al þat ni?t he rode til day, Til he com þer sir Amis lay Vp in þat forest wide. Þan sei?e he [a] weri kni?t forgon Vnder a tre slepeand alon; To him he went þat tide. He cleped to him anon ri?t, “Arise vp, felawe, it is li?t & time for to go!” Sir Amis biheld vp wiþ his si?t & knewe anon þat gentil kni?t, & he knewe him al-so. Þat hendi kni?t, sir Amiloun, Of his stede li?t adoun, & kist hem boþe to. “Broþer,” he seyd, “whi listow here Wiþ þus mornand chere? Who haþ wrou?t þe þis wo?” “Broþer,” seyd sir Amis þo, “Ywis, me nas neuer so wo Seþþen þat y was born; For seþþen þat þou was went me fro, Wiþ ioie & michel blis al-so Y serued mi lord biforn. Ac þe steward ful of envie, Wiþ gile & wiþ trecherie, He haþ me wrou?t swiche sorn; Bot þou help me at þis nede, Certes, y can no noþer rede, Mi liif, it is forlorn!” “Broþer,” seyd sir Amiloun, “Whi haþ þe steward, þat feloun, Ydon þe al þis schame?” “Certes,” he seyd, “wiþ gret tresoun He wald me driuen al adoun & haþ me brou?t in blame.” Þan told sir Amis al þat cas, Hou he & þat maiden was Boþe to-gider ysame, & hou þe steward gan hem wrain, & hou þe douke wald him haue slain Wiþ wretþe & michel grame. & al-so he seyd, ypli?t, Hou he had boden on him fi?t, Batail of him to fong, & hou in court was þer no wi?t, To saue þo tvay leuedis bri?t, Durst ben his borwe among, & hou he most, wiþ-outen faile, Swere, ar he went to bataile, It war a lesing ful strong; “& forsworn man schal neuer spede; Certes, þer-fore y can no rede, ‘Allas’ may be mi song!” When þat sir Amis had al told, Hou þat þe fals steward wold Bring him doun wiþ mode, Sir Amiloun wiþ wordes bold Swore, “Bi him þat Judas sold & died opon þe rode, Of his hope he schal now faile, & y schal for þe take bataile, Þei þat he wer wode; ?if y may mete him ari?t, Wiþ mi brond, þat is so bri?t, Y schal sen his hert blode! Ac broþer,” he seyd, “haue al mi wede, & in þi robe y schal me schrede, Ri?t as þe self it ware; & y schal swere so god me spede As icham giltles of þat dede, Þat he opon þe bare.” Anon þo hendi kni?tes to Alle her wede chaunged þo, & when þai were al ?are, Þan seyd sir Amiloun, “Bi Seyn Gile, Þus man schal þe schrewe bigile, Þat wald þe forfare! Broþer,” he seyd, “wende hom now ri?t To mi leuedi, þat is so bri?t, & do as y schal þe sain; & as þou art a gentil kni?t, Þou ly bi hir in bed ich ni?t, Til þat y com ogain, & sai þou hast sent þi stede ywis To þi broþer, sir Amis; Þan wil þai be ful fain, Þai wil wene þat ich it be; Þer is non þat schal knowe þe, So liche we be boþe tvain!” And when he hadde þus sayd, ypli?t, Sir Amiloun, þat gentil kni?t, Went in his iurnay, & sir Amis went hom anon ri?t To his broþer leuedi so bri?t, Wiþ-outen more delay, & seyd hou he hadde sent his stede To his broþer to riche mede Bi a kni?t of þat cuntray; & al þai wende of sir Amis It had ben her lord, ywis, So liche were þo tvay. When þat sir Amis hadde ful ?are Told him al of his care, Ful wele he wend þo, Litel & michel, lasse & mare, Al þat euer in court ware, Þai þou?t it hadde ben so. & when it was comen to þe ni?t, Sir Amis & þat leuedi bri?t, To bed þai gun go; & whan þai were to-gider ylayd, Sir Amis his swerd out braid & layd bitvix hem tvo. Þe leuedi loked opon him þo Wroþlich wiþ her ei?en tvo, Sche wend hir lord were wode. “Sir,” sche seyd, “whi farstow so? Þus were þou nou?t won to do, Who haþ changed þi mode?” “Dame,” he seyd, “sikerly, Ich haue swiche a malady Þat mengeþ al mi blod, & al min bones be so sare, Y nold nou?t touche þi bodi bare For al þis wardles gode!” Þus, ywis, þat hendy kni?t Was holden in þat fourtenni?t As lord & prince in pride; Ac he for?at him neuer a ni?t, Bitvix him & þat leuedi bri?t His swerd he layd biside. Þe leuedi þou?t in hir resoun, It hadde ben hir lord, sir Amiloun, Þat hadde ben sike þat tide; Þer-fore sche held hir stille þo & wold speke wordes no mo, Bot þou?t his wille to abide. Now, hende, herkeneþ, & y schal say Hou þat sir Amiloun went his way; For no-þing wold he spare. He priked his stede ni?t & day, As a gentil kni?t, stout & gay, To court he com ful ?are Þat selue day, wiþ-outen fail, Þat was ysett of batail, & sir Amis was nou?t þare. Þan were þo leuedis taken bi hond, Her iuggement to vnderstond, Wiþ sorwe & sikeing sare. Þe steward houed opon a stede Wiþ scheld & spere, bataile to bede, Gret bost he gan to blawe; Bifor þe douke anon he ?ede & seyd, “Sir, so god þe spede, Herken to mi sawe! Þis traitour is out of lond ywent; ?if he were here in present, He schuld ben hong & drawe; Þerefore ich aske iugement, Þat his borwes be to-brent, As it is londes lawe.” Þat riche douke, wiþ wreþe & wrake, He bad men schuld þo leuedis take & lede hem forþ biside; A strong fer þer was don make & a tonne for her sake, To bren hem in þat tide. Þan þai loked in to þe feld & sei?e a kni?t wiþ spere & scheld Com prikeand þer wiþ pride. Þan seyd þai euerichon, ywis, “?onder comeþ prikeand sir Amis!” & bad þai schuld abide. Sir Amiloun gan stint at no ston, He priked among hem euerichon, To þat douke he gan wende. “Mi lord þe douke,” he seyd anon, “For schame lete þo leuedis gon, Þat er boþe gode & hende, For ich am comen hider to-day For to sauen hem, ?iue y may, & bring hem out of bende, For, certes, it were michel vnri?t To make roste of leuedis bri?t; Ywis, ?e eren vnkende.” Þan ware þo leuedis glad & bliþe, Her ioie couþe þai noman kiþe, Her care was al oway; & seþþen, as ?e may list & liþe, In-to þe chaunber þai went aswiþe, Wiþ-outen more delay, & richeliche þai schred þat kni?t Wiþ helme & plate & brini bri?t, His tire, it was ful gay. & when he was opon his stede, Þat god him schuld saue & spede Mani man bad þat day. As he com prikand out of toun, Com a voice fram heuen adoun, Þat noman herd bot he, & sayd, “Þou kni?t, sir Amiloun, God, þat suffred passioun, Sent þe bode bi me; ?if þou þis bataile vnderfong, Þou schalt haue an euentour strong Wiþ-in þis ?eres þre; & or þis þre ?ere ben al gon, Fouler mesel nas neuer non In þe world, þan þou schal be! Ac for þou art so hende & fre, Ihesu sent þe bode bi me, To warn þe anon; So foule a wreche þou schalt be, Wiþ sorwe & care & pouerte Nas neuer non wers bigon. Ouer al þis world, fer & hende, Þo þat be þine best frende Schal be þi most fon, & þi wiif & alle þi kinne Schul fle þe stede þatow art inne, & forsake þe ichon.” Þat kni?t gan houe stille so ston & herd þo wordes euerichon, Þat were so gret & grille. He nist what him was best to don, To flen, oþer to fi?ting gon; In hert him liked ille. He þou?t, “?if y beknowe mi name, Þan schal mi broþer go to schame, Wiþ sorwe þai schul him spille. Certes,” he seyd, “for drede of care To hold mi treuþe schal y nou?t spare, Lete god don alle his wille.” Al þe folk þer was, ywis, Þai wend it had ben sir Amis Þat bataile schuld bede; He and þe steward of pris Were brou?t bifor þe iustise To swere for þat dede. Þe steward swore þe pople among, As wis as he seyd no wrong, God help him at his nede; & sir Amiloun swore & gan to say As wis as he neuer kist þat may, Our leuedi schuld him spede. When þai hadde sworn, as y ?ou told, To biker þo bernes were ful bold & busked hem for to ride. Al þat þer was, ?ong & old, Bisou?t god ?if þat he wold Help sir Amis þat tide. On stedes þat were stiþe & strong Þai riden to-gider wiþ schaftes long, Til þai toschiuerd bi ich a side; & þan drou? þai swerdes gode & hewe to-gider, as þai were wode, For noþing þai nold abide. Þo gomes, þat were egre of si?t, Wiþ fauchouns felle þai gun to fi?t & ferd as þai were wode. So hard þai hewe on helmes bri?t Wiþ strong strokes of michel mi?t, Þat fer bi-forn out stode; So hard þai hewe on helme & side, Þurch dent of grimly woundes wide, Þat þai sprad al of blod. Fram morwe to none, wiþ-outen faile, Bitvixen hem last þe bataile, So egre þai were of mode. Sir Amiloun, as fer of flint, Wiþ wretþe anon to him he wint & smot a stroke wiþ main; Ac he failed of his dint, Þe stede in þe heued he hint & smot out al his brain. Þe stede fel ded doun to grounde; Þo was þe steward þat stounde Ful ferd he schuld be slain. Sir Amiloun li?t adoun of his stede, To þe steward a-fot he ?ede & halp him vp ogain. “Arise vp, steward,” he seyd anon, “To fi?t þou schalt a-fot gon, For þou hast lorn þi stede; For it were gret vilani, bi Seyn Jon, A liggeand man for to slon, Þat were yfallen in nede.” Þat kni?t was ful fre to fond & tok þe steward bi þe hond & seyd, “So god me spede, Now þou schalt a-fot go, Y schal fi?t a-fot al-so, & elles were gret falshed.” Þe steward & þat douhti man Anon to-gider þai fi?t gan Wiþ brondes bri?t & bare; So hard to-gider þai fi?t þan, Til al her armour o blod ran, For noþing nold þai spare. Þe steward smot to him þat stounde On his schulder a gret wounde Wiþ his grimly gare, Þat þurch þat wounde, as ?e may here, He was knowen wiþ reweli chere, When he was fallen in care. Þan was sir Amiloun wroþ & wode, Whan al his armour ran o blode, Þat ere was white so swan; Wiþ a fauchoun scharp & gode He smot to him wiþ egre mode Al so a douhti man, Þat euen fro þe schulder-blade In-to þe brest þe brond gan wade, Þurch-out his hert it ran. Þe steward fel adoun ded, Sir Amiloun strok of his hed, & god he þonked it þan. Alle þe lordinges þat þer ware, Litel & michel, lasse & mare, Ful glad þai were þat tide. Þe heued opon a spere þai bare; To toun þai di?t hem ful ?are, For noþing þai nold abide; Þai com o?aines him out of toun Wiþ a fair processioun Semliche bi ich a side. Anon þai ladde him to þe tour Wiþ ioie & ful michel honour, As prince proude in pride. In to þe palais when þai were gon, Al þat was in þat worþli won Wende sir Amis it ware. “Sir Amis,” seyd þe douke anon, “Bifor þis lordinges euerichon Y graunt þe ful ?are, For Belisent, þat miri may, Þou hast bou?t hir ful dere to day Wiþ grimli woundes sare; Þer-fore y graunt þe now here Mi lond & mi douhter dere, To hald for euer mare.” Ful bliþe was þat hendi kni?t & þonked him wiþ al his mi?t, Glad he was & fain; In alle þe court was þer no wi?t Þat wist wat his name it hi?t, To saue þo leuedis tvain, Leches swiþe þai han yfounde, Þat gun to tasty his wounde & made him hole ogain, Þan were þai al glad & bliþe & þonked god a þousand siþe Þat þe steward was slain. On a day sir Amiloun di?t him ?are & seyd þat he wold fare Hom in to his cuntray To telle his frendes, lasse & mare, & oþer lordinges þat þere ware, Hou he had sped þat day. Þe douke graunted him þat tide & bede him kni?tes & miche pride, & he answerd, “Nay.” Þer schuld noman wiþ him gon, Bot as swiþe him di?t anon & went forþ in his way. In his way he went alone, Most þer noman wiþ him gon, Noiþer kni?t no swain. Þat douhti kni?t of blod & bon, No stint he neuer at no ston Til he com hom ogain; & sir Amis, as y ?ou say, Waited his coming eueri day Vp in þe forest plain; & so þai mett to-gider same, & he teld him wiþ ioie & game Hou he hadde þe steward slain, & hou he schuld spousy to mede Þat ich maide, worþli in wede, Þat was so comly corn. Sir Amiloun li?t of his stede, & gan to chaungy her wede, As þai hadde don biforn. “Broþer,” he seyd, “wende hom ogain.” & tau?t him hou he schuld sain, When he com þer þai worn. Þan was sir Amis glad & bliþe & þanked him a þousand siþe Þe time þat he was born. & when þai schuld wende ato, Sir Amis oft þonked him þo His cost & his gode dede. “Broþer,” he seyd, “?if it bitide so Þat þe bitide care oþer wo, & of min help hast nede, Sauelich com oþer sende þi sond, & y schal neuer lenger wiþstond, Al so god me spede; Be it in periil neuer so strong, Y schal þe help in ri?t & wrong, Mi liif to lese to mede.” A sonder þan þai gun wende; Sir Amiloun, þat kni?t so hende, Went hom in þat tide To his leuedi þat was vnkende, & was ful welcome to his frende, As prince proude in pride; & when it was comen to þe ni?t, Sir Amiloun & þat leuedi bri?t In bedde were layd biside; In his armes he gan hir kis & made his ioie & michel blis, For noþing he nold abide. Þe leuedi astite asked him þo Whi þat he hadde farn so Al þat fourtenni?t, Laid his swerd bitven hem to, Þat sche no durst nou?t for wele no wo Touche his bodi ari?t. Sir Amiloun biþou?t him þan His broþer was a trewe man, Þat hadde so done, apli?t. “Dame,” he seyd, “ichil þe sain & telle þe þat soþe ful fain, Ac wray me to no wi?t.” Þe leuedi astite him frain gan, For his loue, þat þis warld wan, Telle hir whi it ware. Þan astite þat hendy man, Al þe soþe he teld hir þan, To court hou he gan fare, & hou he slou? þe steward strong, Þat wiþ tresoun & wiþ wrong Wold haue his broþer forfare, & hou his broþer þat hendy kni?t Lay wiþ hir in bed ich ni?t While þat he was þare. Þe leuedi was ful wroþ, ypli?t, & oft missayd hir lord þat ni?t Wiþ speche bitvix hem to, & seyd, “Wiþ wrong & michel vnri?t Þou slou? þer a gentil kni?t; Ywis, it was iuel ydo!” “Dame,” he seyd, “bi heuen king, Y no dede it for non oþer þing Bot to saue mi broþer fro wo, & ich hope, ?if ich hadde nede, His owhen liif to lesse to mede, He wald help me al-so.” Al þus, in gest as we sain, Sir Amis was ful glad & fain, To court he gan to wende; & when he come to court o?ain Wiþ erl, baroun, kni?t & swain, Honourd he was, þat hende. Þat riche douke tok him bi hond & sesed him in alle his lond, To held wiþ-outen ende; & seþþen wiþ ioie opon a day He spoused Belisent, þat may, Þat was so trewe & kende. Miche was þat semly folk in sale, Þat was samned at þat bridale When he hadde spoused þat flour, Of erls, barouns, mani & fale, & oþer lordinges gret & smale, & leuedis bri?t in bour. A real fest þai gan to hold Of erls & of barouns bold Wiþ ioie & michel honour; Ouer al þat lond est & west Þan was sir Amis helden þe best & chosen for priis in tour. So wiþ-in þo ?eres to A wel fair grace fel hem þo, As god almi?ti wold; Þe riche douke dyed hem fro & his leuedi dede al-so, & grauen in grete so cold. Þan was sir Amis, hende & fre, Douke & lord of gret pouste Ouer al þat lond yhold. Tvai childer he bi?at bi his wiue, Þe fairest þat mi?t bere liue, In gest as it is told. Þan was þat kni?t of gret renoun & lord of mani a tour & toun & douke of gret pouste; & his broþer, Sir Amiloun, Wiþ sorwe & care was driuen adoun, Þat ere was hende & fre; Al so þat angel hadde him told, Fouler messel þar nas non hold In world þan was he. In gest to rede it is gret rewþe, What sorwe he hadde for his treuþe Wiþ-in þo ?eres þre. & er þo þre ?ere come to þende He no wist whider he mi?t wende, So wo was him bigon; For al þat were his best frende, & nameliche al his riche kende, Bicom his most fon; & his wiif, for soþe to say, Wrou?t him wers boþe ni?t & day Þan þai dede euerichon. When him was fallen þat hard cas, A frendeleser man þan he was Men nist no-whar non. So wicked & schrewed was his wiif, Sche brac his hert wiþ-outen kniif, Wiþ wordes harde & kene, & seyd to him, “Þou wreche chaitif, Wiþ wrong þe steward les his liif, & þat is on þe sene; Þer-fore, bi Seyn Denis of Fraunce, Þe is bitid þis hard chaunce, Daþet who þe bimene!” Wel oft times his honden he wrong, As man þat þenkeþ his liif to long, Þat liueþ in treye & tene. Allas, allas! þat gentil kni?t Þat whilom was so wise & wi?t, Þat þan was wrou?t so wo, Þat fram his leuedi, fair & bri?t, Out of his owhen chaumber a-ni?t He was yhote to go, & in his owhen halle o-day Fram þe hei?e bord oway He was ycharged al-so To eten at þe tables ende; Wald þer no man sit him hende, Wel careful was he þo. Bi þan þat half ?ere was ago Þat he hadde eten in halle so Wiþ gode mete & wiþ drink, His leuedi wax ful wroþ & wo & þou?t he liued to long þo— Wiþ-outen ani lesing— “In þis lond springeþ þis word, Y fede a mesel at mi bord, He is so foule a þing, It is gret spite to al mi kende, He schal no more sitt me so hende, Bi Ihesus, heuen king!” On a day sche gan him calle & seyd, “Sir, it is so bifalle, For soþe, y telle it te, Þat þou etest so long in halle, It is gret spite to ous alle, Mi kende is wroþ wiþ me.” Þe kni?t gan wepe & seyd ful stille, “Do me where it is þi wille, Þer noman may me se; Of no more ichil þe praye, Bot of a meles mete ich day, For seynt charite.” Þat leuedi, for hir lordes sake, Anon sche dede men timber take, For noþing wold sche wond, & half a mile fram þe gate A litel loge sche lete make, Biside þe way to stond. & when þe loge was al wrou?t, Of his gode no wold he no?t, Bot his gold coupe an hond. When he was in his loge alon, To god of heuen he made his mon & þonked him of al his sond. In-to þat loge when he was di?t, In al þe court was þer no wi?t Þat wold serue him þare, To saue a gentil child, ypli?t, Child Owaines his name it hi?t, For him he wepe ful sare. Þat child was trewe & of his kende, His soster sone, he was ful hende; He sayd to hem ful ?are, Ywis, he no schuld neuer wond To seruen him fro fot to hond, While he oliues ware. Þat child, þat was so fair & bold, Owaines was his name ytold, Wel fair he was of blode. When he was of tvelue ?ere old, Amoraunt þan was he cald, Wel curteys, hend & gode. Bi his lord ich ni?t he lay & feched her liuere euer day To her liues fode. When ich man made gle & song, Euer for his lord among He made dreri mode. Þus Amoraunt, as y ?ou say, Com to court ich day, No stint he for no striue. Al þat þer was gan him pray To com fro þat lazer oway, Þan schuld he the & þriue. & he answerd wiþ milde mode & swore bi him þat dyed on rode & þoled woundes fiue, For al þis worldes gode to take His lord nold he neuer forsake Whiles he ware oliue. Bi þan þe tvelmoneþ was al gon, Amorant went in-to þat won For his lordes liueray; Þe leuedi was ful wroþ anon & comaunde hir men euerichon To driue þat child oway, & swore bi him þat Judas sold, Þei his lord for hunger & cold Dyed þer he lay, He schuld haue noiþer mete no drink, No socour of non oþer þing For hir after þat day. Þat child wrong his honden tvain & weping went hom ogain Wiþ sorwe & sikeing sare. Þat godeman gan him frain & bad him þat he schuld him sain & telle him whi it ware. & he answerd & seyd þo, “Ywis, no wonder þei me be wo, Mine hert, it brekeþ for care; Þi wiif haþ [sworn] wiþ gret mode Þat sche no schal neuer don ous gode; Allas, hou schal we fare?” “A, god help!” seyd þat gentil kni?t, “Whilom y was man of mi?t, To dele mete & cloþ, & now icham so foule a wi?t Þat al þat seþ on me bi si?t, Mi liif is hem ful loþ. “Sone,” he seyd, “lete þi wepeing, For þis is now a strong tiding, Þat may we se for soþ; For, certes, y can non oþer red, Ous bihoueþ to bid our brede, Now y wot hou it goþ.” Amorwe astite as it was li?t, Þe child & þat gentil kni?t Di?t hem for to gon, & in her way þai went ful ri?t To begge her brede, as þai hadde ti?t, For mete no hadde þai none. So long þai went vp & doun Til þai com to a chepeing-toun, Fiue mile out of þat won, & sore wepeand fro dore to dore, & bad here mete for godes loue, Ful iuel couþe þai þer-on. So in þat time, ich vnderstond, Gret plente was in þat lond, Boþe of mete & drink; Þat folk was ful fre to fond & brou?t hem anou? to hond Of al kines þing; For þe gode man was so messaner þo, & for þe child was fair al-so, Hem loued old & ?ing, & brou?t hem anou? of al gode; Þan was þe child bliþe of mode & lete be his wepeing. Þan wex þe gode man fote so sare Þat he no mi?t no forþer fare For al þis worldes gode; To þe tounes ende þat child him bare & a loge he bilt him þare, As folk to chepeing ?ode; & as þat folk of þat cuntray Com to chepeing eueri day, Þai gat hem liues fode; & Amoraunt oft to toun gan go & begged hem mete & drink also, When hem most nede at-stode. Þus in gest rede we Þai duelled þere ?eres þre, Þat child & he al-so, & liued in care & pouerte Bi þe folk of þat cuntre, As þai com to & fro, So þat in þe ferþ ?ere Corn bigan to wex dere, Þat hunger bigan to go, Þat þer was noiþer eld no ?ing Þat wald ?if hem mete no drink, Wel careful were þai þo. Amorant oft to toun gan gon, Ac mete no drink no gat he non, Noiþer at man no wiue. When þai were to-gider al-on, Reweliche þai gan maken her mon, Wo was hem o liue; & his leuedi, for soþe to say, Woned þer in þat cuntray Nou?t þennes miles fiue, & liued in ioie boþe ni?t & day, Whiles he in sorwe & care lay, Wel iuel mot sche þriue! On a day, as þai sete alon, Þat hendi kni?t gan meken his mon & seyd to þe child þat tide,— “Sone,” he seyd, “þou most gon To mi leuedi swiþe anon, Þat woneþ here biside, Bid hir, for him þat died on rode, Sende me so michel of al mi gode, An asse, on to ride, & out of lond we wil fare To begge our mete wiþ sorwe & care, No lenger we nil abide.” Amoraunt to court is went Bifor þat leuedi fair & gent, Wel hendeliche seyd hir anon, “Madame,” he seyd, “verrament, As me[s]sanger mi lord me sent, For him-self may nou?t gon, & praieste wiþ milde mode Sende him so michel of al his gode As an asse to riden opon, & out of lond we schulen yfere, No schal we neuer com eft here, Þei hunger ous schuld slon.” Þe leuedi seyd sche wald ful fain Sende him gode asses tvain, Wiþ þi he wald oway go So fer þat he neuer eft com ogain. “Nat, certes, dame,” þe child gan sain, “Þou sest ous neuer eft mo.” Þan was þe leuedi glad & bliþe & comaund him an asse as swiþe & seyd wiþ wretþe þo, “Now ?e schul out of lond fare, God leue ?ou neuer to com here mare, & graunt þat it be so.” Þat child no lenger nold abide, His asse astite he gan bistride & went him hom ogain, & told his lord in þat tide Hou his leuedi proude in pride Schameliche gan to sain; Opon þe asse he sett þat kni?t so hende, & out of þe cite þai gun wende; Þer of þai were ful fain. Þurch mani a cuntre, vp an doun, Þai begged her mete fram toun to toun, Boþe in winde & rain. Ouer al þat lond þurch godes wille Þat hunger wex so gret & grille, As wide as þai gun go; Al-mest for hunger þai gan to spille, Of brede þai no hadde nou?t half her fille, Ful careful were þai þo. Þan seyd þe kni?t opon a day, “Ous bihoueþ selle our asse oway, For we no haue gode no mo, Saue mi riche coupe of gold, Ac certes, þat schal neuer be sold, Þei hunger schuld me slo.” Þan Amoraunt & sir Amiloun, Wiþ sorwe & care & reweful roun Erliche in a morning Þai went him til a chepeing-toun, & when þe kni?t was li?t adoun, Wiþ-outen ani duelling, Amoraunt went to toun þo, His asse he ladde wiþ him also & sold it for fiue schilling. & while þat derþ was so strong, Þer wiþ þai bou?t hem mete among, When þai mi?t gete no þing. & when her asse was ysold For fiue schilling, as y ?ou told, Þai duelled þer dayes þre; Amoraunt wex strong & bold, Of fiftene winter was he old, Curtays, hende & fre. For his lord he hadde grete care, & at his rigge he di?t him ?are & bare him out of þat cite; & half a ?ere & sum del mare About his mete he him bare, Yblisced mot he be. Þus Amoraunt, wiþ-outen wrong, Bar his lord about so long, As y ?ou tel may. Þat winter com so hard & strong, Oft, “Allas!” it was his song, So depe was þat cuntray; Þe way was so depe & slider, Oft times boþe to-gider Þai fel doun in þe clay. Ful trewe he was & kinde of blod & serued his lord wiþ mild mode, Wald he nou?t wende oway. Þus Amoraunt, as y ?ou say, Serued his lord boþe ni?t & day & at his rigge him bare. Oft his song was, “Waileway!” So depe was þat cuntray, His bones wex ful sare. Al her catel þan was spent, Saue tvelf pans, verrament, Þerwiþ þai went ful ?are & bou?t hem a gode croude-wain, His lord he gan þer-in to lain, He no mi?t him bere namare. Þan Amoraunt crud sir Amiloun Þurch mani a cuntre, vp & doun, As ?e may vnderstond; So he com to a cite toun, Þer sir Amis, þe bold baroun, Was douke & lord in lond. Þan seyd þe kni?t in þat tide, “To þe doukes court here biside To bring me þider þou fond; He is a man of milde mode, We schul gete ous þer sum gode Þurch grace of godes sond. “Ac, leue sone,” he seyd þan, “For his loue, þat þis world wan Astow art hende & fre, Þou be aknowe to no man Whider y schal, no whenes y cam, No what mi name it be.” He answerd & seyd, “Nay.” To court he went in his way, As ?e may listen at me, & bifor al oþer pouer men He crud his wain in to þe fen; Gret diol it was to se. So it bifel þat selue day,— Wiþ tong as y ?ou tel may,— It was midwinter tide, Þat riche douke wiþ gamen & play Fram chirche com þe ri?t way As lord & prince wiþ pride. When he com to þe castel-gate, Þe pouer men þat stode þer-ate Wiþdrou? hem þer beside. Wiþ kni?tes & wiþ seriaunce fale He went in-to þat semly sale Wiþ ioie & blis to abide. In kinges court, as it is lawe, Trumpes in halle to mete gan blawe, To benche went þo bold. When þai were semly set on rowe, Serued þai were opon a þrowe, As men miriest on mold. Þat riche douke, wiþ-outen les, As a prince serued he wes Wiþ riche coupes of gold, & he þat brou?t him to þat state Stode bischet wiþ-outen þe gate, Wel sore of-hungred & cold. Out at þe gate com a kni?t & a seriaunt wise & wi?t, To plain hem boþe yfere, & þurch þe grace of god almi?t On sir Amiloun he cast a si?t, Hou laiþ he was of chere. & seþþen biheld on Amoraunt, Hou gentil he was & of fair semblaunt, In gest as ?e may here. Þan seyd þai boþe, bi Seyn Jon, In al þe court was þer non Of fairehed half his pere. Þe gode man gan to him go, & hendeliche he asked him þo, As ?e may vnderstond, Fram wat lond þat he com fro, & whi þat he stode þer þo, & whom he serued in lond. “Sir,” he seyd, “so god me saue, Icham here mi lordes knaue, Þat liþ in godes bond; & þou art gentil kni?t of blode, Bere our erand of sum gode Þurch grace of godes sond.” Þe gode man asked him anon, ?if he wald fro þat lazer gon & trewelich to him take; & he seyd he schuld, bi Seyn Jon, Serue þat riche douke in þat won, & richeman he wald him make; & he answerd wiþ mild mode & swore bi him þat dyed on rode Whiles he mi?t walk & wake, For to winne al þis warldes gode, His hende lord, þat bi him stode, Schuld he neuer forsake. Þe gode man wende he hadde ben rage, Or he hadde ben a fole-sage Þat hadde his witt forlorn, Oþer he þou?t þat his lord wiþ þe foule visage Hadde ben a man of hei?e parage & of hei?e kinde ycorn. Þer-fore he nold no more sain, Bot went him in to þe halle ogain Þe riche douke biforn, “Mi lord,” he seyd, “listen to me Þe best bourd, bi mi leuete, Þou herdest seþþen þou were born.” Þe riche douke badde him anon To telle bi-forn hem euerichon Wiþ-outen more duelling. “Now sir,” he seyd, “bi Seyn Jon, Ich was out atte gate ygon Ri?t now on mi playing; Pouer men y sei?e mani þare, Litel & michel, lasse & mare, Boþe old & ?ing, & a lazer þer y fond; Herdestow neuer in no lond Telle of so foule a þing. “Þe lazer liþ vp in a wain, & is so pouer of mi?t & main O fot no may he gon; & ouer him stode a naked swain, A gentiler child, for soþe to sain, In world no wot y non. He is þe fairest gome Þat euer Crist ?af cristendome Or layd liif opon, & on of þe most fole he is Þat euer þou herdest speke, ywis, In þis worldes won.” Þan seyd þe riche douke ogain, “What foly,” he seyd, “can he sain? Is he madde of mode?” “Sir,” he seyd, “y bad him fain Forsake þe lazer in þe wain, Þat he so ouer stode, & in þi seruise he schuld be, Y bihete him boþe lond & fe, Anou? of warldes gode; & he answerd & seyd þo He nold neuer gon him fro; Þer-fore ich hold him wode.” Þan seyd þe douke, “Þei his lord be lorn, Par auentour, þe gode man haþ biforn Holpen him at his nede, Oþer þe child is of his blod yborn, Oþer he haþ him oþes sworn His liif wiþ him to lede. Wheþer he be fremd or of his blod, Þe child,” he seyd, “is trewe & gode, Also god me spede. ?if ichim speke er he wende, For þat he is so trewe & kende, Y schal quite him his mede!” Þat douke astite, as y ?ou told, Cleped to him a squier bold & hendelich gan him sain: “Take,” he sayd, “mi coupe of gold, As ful of wine astow mi?t hold In þine hondes tvain, & bere it to þe castel-?ate, A lazer þou schalt finde þerate Liggeand in a wain. Bid him, for þe loue of Seyn Martin, He and his page drink þis win, & bring me þe coupe ogain.” Þe squier þo þe coupe hent, & to þe castel-gat he went, & ful of win he it bare. To þe lazer he seyd, verrament, “Þis coupe ful of win mi lord þe sent, Drink it, ?iue þou dare.” Þe lazer tok forþ his coupe of gold, Boþe were ?oten in o mold, Ri?t as þat selue it ware, Þer-in he pourd þat win so riche; Þan were þai boþe ful yliche & noiþer lesse no mare. Þe squier biheld þe coupes þo, First his & his lordes al-so, Whiles he stode hem biforn, Ac he no couþe neuer mo Chese þe better of hem to, So liche boþe þai worn. In-to halle he ran ogain, “Certes, sir,” he gan to sain, “Mani gode dede þou hast lorn, & so þou hast lorn þis dede now; He is a richer man þan þou, Bi þe time þat god was born.” Þe riche douke answerd, “Nay. Þat worþ neuer bi ni?t no day, It were o?aines þe lawe!” “?is, sir,” he gan to say, “He is a traitour, bi mi fay, & were wele worþ to drawe. For when y brou?t him þe win, He drou? forþ a gold coupe fin, Ri?t as it ware þi nawe; In þis world, bi Seyn Jon, So wise a man is þer non Asundri schuld hem knawe.” “Now, certes,” seyd sir Amis þo, “In al þis world were coupes nomo So liche in al þing, Saue min & mi broþers al-so, Þat was sett bitvix ous to, Token of our parting; & ?if it be so, wiþ tresoun Mine hende broþer, sir Amiloun, Is slain, wiþ-outen lesing. & ?if he haue stollen his coupe oway, Y schal him sle me self þis day, Bi Ihesu, heuen king!” Fram þe bord he resed þan & hent his swerd as a wode man & drou? it out wiþ wrake, & to þe castel gat he ran; In al þe court was þer no man Þat him mi?t atake. To þe lazer he stirt in þe wain & hent him in his honden tvain & sleynt him in þe lake, & layd on, as he were wode, & al þat euer about him stode Gret diol gan make. “Traitour!” seyd þe douke so bold, “Where haddestow þis coupe of gold & hou com þou þer to? For bi him at Judas sold, Amiloun, mi broþer, it hadde in wold, When þat he went me fro!” “?a, certes, sir,” he gan to say, “It was his in his cuntray, & now it is fallen so; Bot certes, now þat icham here, Þe coupe is mine, y bou?t it dere, Wiþ ri?t y com þer to.” Þan was þe douke ful egre of mod; Was noman þat about him stode Þat durst legge on him hond; He spurned him wiþ his fot & laid on, as he were wode, Wiþ his naked brond, & bi þe fet þe lazer he drou? & drad on him in þe slou?; For no þing wald he wond, & seyd, “Þef, þou schalt be slawe, Bot þou wilt be þe soþe aknawe, Where þou þe coupe fond.” Child Amoraunt stode þe pople among & seye his lord wiþ wou? & wrong Hou reweliche he was di?t. He was boþe hardi & strong, Þe douke in his armes he fong & held him stille vp-ri?t. “Sir,” he seyd, “þou art vnhende & of þi werkes vnkende, To sle þat gentil kni?t. Wel sore may him rewe þat stounde Þat euer for þe toke he wounde To saue þi liif in fi?t. “And ys thi brother, sir Amylioun, That whilom was a noble baroun Bothe to ryde and go, And now with sorwe ys dreue adoun; Nowe god þat suffred passioun Breng him oute of his wo! For the of blysse he ys bare, And thou yeldyst him all with care And brekest his bones a two; That he halp the at thi nede, Well euell aquitest thou his mede, Alas, whi farest thou so?” When sir Amis herd him so sain, He stirt to þe kni?t ogain, Wiþ-outen more delay, & biclept him in his armes tvain, & oft, “Allas!” he gan sain; His song was “Waileway!” He loked opon his scholder bare & sei?e his grimly wounde þare, As Amoraunt gan him say. He fel aswon to þe grounde & oft he seyd, “Allas þat stounde!” Þat euer he bode þat day. “Allas,” he seyd, “mi ioie is lorn, Vnkender blod nas neuer born, Y not wat y may do; For he saued mi liif biforn, Ichaue him ?olden wiþ wo & sorn & wrou?t him michel wo. “O broþer,” he seyd, “par charite, Þis rewely dede for?if þou me, Þat ichaue smiten þe so!” & he for?aue it him also swiþe & kist him wel mani a siþe, Wepeand wiþ ei?en tvo. Þan was sir Amis glad & fain, For ioie he wepe wiþ his ain & hent his broþer þan, & tok him in his armes tvain, Ri?t til he come in-to þe halle o?ain, No bar him no noþer man. Þe leuedi þo in þe halle stode & wend hir lord hadde ben wode, O?aines him hye ran. “Sir,” sche seyd, “wat is þi þou?t? Whi hastow him in-to halle ybrou?t, For him þat þis world wan?” “O dame,” he seyd, “bi Seyn Jon, Me nas neuer so wo bigon, ?if þou it wost vnderstond, For better kni?t in world is non, Bot al-most now ichaue him slon & schamely driuen to schond; For it is mi broþer, sir Amiloun, Wiþ sorwe & care is dreuen adoun, Þat er was fre to fond.” Þe leuedi fel aswon to grounde & wepe & seyd, “Allas þat stounde!” Wel sore wrengand hir hond. As foule a lazer as he was, Þe leuedi kist him in þat plas, For noþing wold sche spare, & oft time sche seyd, “Allas!” Þat him was fallen so hard a cas, To liue in sorwe & care. Into hir chaumber she gan him lede & kest of al his pouer wede & baþed his bodi al bare, & to a bedde swiþe him brou?t Wiþ cloþes riche & wele ywrou?t; Ful bliþe of him þai ware. & þus in gest as we say, Tvelmoneþ in her chaumber he lay, Ful trewe þai ware & kinde. No wold þai nick him wiþ no nay, What so euer he asked ni?t or day, It nas neuer bihinde; Of euerich mete & eueri drink Þai had hem-selue, wiþ-outen lesing, Þai were him boþe ful minde. & biþan þe tvelmonþ was ago, A ful fair grace fel hem þo, In gest as we finde. So it bifel opon a ni?t, As sir Amis, þat gentil kni?t, In slepe þou?t as he lay, An angel com fram heuen bri?t & stode biforn his bed ful ri?t & to him þus gan say: ?if he wald rise on Cristes morn, Swiche time as Ihesu Crist was born, & slen his children tvay, & alien his [broþer] wiþ þe blode, Þurch godes grace, þat is so gode, His wo schuld wende oway. Þus him þou?t al þo þre ni?t An angel out of heuen bri?t Warned him euer more ?if he wald do as he him hi?t, His broþer schuld ben as fair a kni?t As euer he was biforn, Ful bliþe was sir Amis þo, Ac for his childer him was ful wo, For fairer ner non born. Wel loþ him was his childer to slo, & wele loþer his broþer forgo, Þat is so kinde ycorn. Sir Amiloun met þat ni?t also Þat an angel warned him þo & seyd to him ful ?are, ?if his broþer wald his childer slo, Þe hert blod of hem to Mi?t bring him out of care. A morwe sir Amis was ful hende & to his broþer he gan wende & asked him of his fare; & he him answerd o?ain ful stille, “Broþer, ich abide her godes wille, For y may do na mare.” Al so þai sete to-gider þare & speke of auentours, as it ware, Þo kni?tes hende & fre, Þan seyd sir Amiloun ful ?are, “Broþer, y nil nou?t spare To tel þe in priuite Me þou?t to-ni?t in mi sweuen Þat an angel com fram heuen; For soþe, he told me Þat þurch þe blod of [þin] children to Y mi?t aschape out of mi wo, Al hayl & hole to be!” Þan þou?t þe douk, wiþ-outen lesing, For to slen his childer so ?ing, It were a dedli sinne; & þan þou?t he, bi heuen king, His broþer out of sorwe bring, For þat nold he nou?t blinne. So it bifel on Cristes ni?t, Swiche time as Ihesu, ful of mi?t, Was born to saue man-kunne, To chirche to wende al þat þer wes, Þai di?ten hem, wiþ-outen les, Wiþ ioie & worldes winne. Þan þai were redi for to fare, Þe douke bad al þat þer ware, To chirche þai schuld wende, Litel & michel, lasse & mare, Þat non bileft in chaumber þare, As þai wald ben his frende, & seyd he wald him-selue þat ni?t Kepe his broþer þat gentil kni?t Þat was so god & kende. Þan was þer non þat durst say nay; To chirche þai went in her way, At hom bileft þo hende. Þe douke wel fast gan aspie Þe kays of þe noricerie, Er þan þai schuld gon, & priueliche he cast his ei?e & aparceiued ful witterlye Where þat þai hadde hem don. & when þai were to chirche went, Þan sir Amis, verrament, Was bileft al-on. He tok a candel fair & bri?t & to þe kays he went ful ri?t & tok hem oway ichon. Alon him self, wiþ-outen mo, Into þe chaumber he gan to go, Þer þat his childer were, & biheld hem boþe to, Hou fair þai lay to-gider þo & slepe boþe yfere. Þan seyd him-selue, “Bi Seyn Jon, It were gret reweþe ?ou to slon, Þat god haþ bou?t so dere!” His kniif he had drawen þat tide, For sorwe he sleynt oway biside & wepe wiþ reweful chere. Þan he hadde wopen þer he stode, Anon he turned o?ain his mode & sayd wiþ-outen delay, “Mi broþer was so kinde & gode, Wiþ grimly wounde he schad his blod For mi loue opon a day; Whi schuld y þan mi childer spare, To bring mi broþer out of care? O, certes,” he seyd, “nay! To help mi broþer now at þis nede, God graunt me þer-to wele to spede, & Mari, þat best may!” No lenger stint he no stode, Bot hent his kniif wiþ dreri mode & tok his children þo; For he nold nou?t spille her blode, Ouer a bacine fair & gode Her þrotes he schar atvo. & when he hadde hem boþe slain, He laid hem in her bed ogain, —No wonder þei him were wo— & hilde hem, þat no wi?t schuld se, As noman hadde at hem be; Out of chaumber he gan go. & when he was out of chaumber gon, Þe dore he steked stille anon As fast as it was biforn; Þe kays he hidde vnder a ston & þou?t þai schuld wene ichon Þat þai hadde ben forlorn. To his broþer he went him þan & seyd to þat careful man, “Swiche time as god was born, Ich haue þe brou?t mi childer blod, Ich hope it schal do þe gode As þe angel seyd biforn.” “Broþer,” sir Amiloun gan to say, “Hastow slayn þine children tvay? Allas, whi destow so?” He wepe & seyd, “Waileway! Ich had leuer til domesday Haue liued in care & wo!” Þan seyd sir Amis, “Be now stille; Ihesu, when it is his wille, May send me childer mo. For me of blis þou art al bare; Ywis, mi liif wil y nou?t spare, To help þe now þer-fro.” He tok þat blode, þat was so bri?t, & alied þat gentil kni?t, Þat er was hend in hale, & seþþen in bed him di?t & wrei?e him wel warm, apli?t, Wiþ cloþes riche & fale. “Broþer,” he seyd, “ly now stille & falle on slepe þurch godes wille, As þe angel told in tale; & ich hope wele wiþ-outen lesing, Ihesu, þat is heuen king, Schal bote þe of þi bale.” Sir Amis let him ly alon & in to his chapel he went anon, In gest as ?e may here, & for his childer, þat he hadde slon, To god of heuen he made his mon & preyd wiþ rewely chere Schuld saue him fram schame þat day, & Mari, his moder, þat best may, Þat was him leue & dere; & Ihesu Crist, in þat stede Ful wele he herd þat kni?tes bede & graunt him his praiere. A morwe astite as it was day, Þe leuedi com home al wiþ play Wiþ kni?tes ten & fiue; Þai sou?t þe kays þer þai lay; Þai founde hem nou?t, þai were oway, Wel wo was hem o-liue. Þe douk bad al þat þer wes Þai schuld hold hem still in pes & stint of her striue, & seyd he hadde þe keys nome, Schuld noman in þe chaumber come Bot him self & his wiue. Anon he tok his leuedi þan & seyd to hir, “Leue leman, Be bliþe & glad of mode; For bi him þat þis warld wan, Boþe mi childer ich haue slan, Þat were so hende & gode; For me þou?t in mi sweuen Þat an angel com fram heuen & seyd me þurch her blode Mi broþer schuld passe out of his wo; Þer-fore y slou? hem boþe to, To hele þat frely fode.” Þan was þe leuedi ferly wo & sei?e hir lord was al-so; Sche comfort him ful ?are, “O lef liif,” sche seyd þo, “God may sende ous childer mo, Of hem haue þou no care. ?if it ware at min hert rote, For to bring þi broþer bote, My lyf y wold not spare. Shal noman oure children see, To-morrow shal þey beryed bee As þey faire ded ware!” Þus þe lady faire & bry?t Comfort hur lord with al hur my?t, As ?e mow vnderstonde; And seth þey went boþ ful ry?t To sir Amylion, þat gentyl kny?t, Þat ere was free to fonde. When sir Amylion wakyd þoo, Al his fowlehed was agoo Þrou? grace of goddes sonde; Þan was he as feire a man As euer he was ?et or þan, Seþ he was born in londe. Þan were þey al bliþ, Her ioy couþ noman kyth, Þey þonked god þat day. As ?e mow listen and lyth, Into a chamber þey went swyþ, Þer þe children lay; With-out wemme and wound Hool and sound þe children found, And layen to-geder and play. For ioye þey wept, þere þey stood, And þanked god with myld mood, Her care was al [away]. When sir Amylion was hool & fere And wax was strong of powere Boþ to goo and ryde, Child Oweys was a bold squyer, Blithe and glad he was of chere, To serue his lord beside. Þan saide þe kny?t vppon a day, He wolde hoom to his contray, To speke with his wyf þat tyde; And for she halp him so at nede, Wel he þou?t to quyte hur mede, No lenger wold he abyde. Sir Amys sent ful hastely After mony kny?t hardy, Þat dou?ty were of dede, Wel fyue hundred kene and try, And other barons by and by On palfray and on steed. He preked both ny?t and day Til he com to his contray, Þer he was lord in lede. Þan had a kny?t of þat contre Spoused his lady, bry?t of ble, In romaunce as we rede. But þus, in romaunce as y ?ow say, Þey com hoom þat silf day Þat þe bridal was hold; To þe ?ates þey preked with-out delay, Anon þer began a soory play Among þe barouns bold. A messengere to þe hal com And seide her lord was com hom As man meriest on molde. Þan wox þe lady blew and wan, Þer was mony a sory man, Boþ ?ong and olde. Sir Amys and sir Amylion And with hem mony a stout baron With kny?tes & squyers fale, With helmes & with haberyon, With swerd bry?t and broun, Þey went in to þe hale. Al þat þey þere arau?t, Grete strokes þere þey cau?t, Boþ grete and smale. Glad and blyþ were þey þat day, Who so my?t skape away [And fle fro that bredale]. [When thei had with wrake Droue oute both broun and blake] Out of þat worthy woon, Sir Amylyon for his lady sake & grete logge he let make Boþ of lym and stoon. Þere-yn was þe lady ladde And with bred and water was she fed, Tyl her lyue-days were goon. Þus was þe lady brou?t to dede, Who þerof rou?t, he was a queede, As ?e haue herd echoon. Þen sir Amylion sent his sond To erles, barouns, fre and bond, Boþ feire and hende. When þey com, he sesed in hond Child Oweys in al his lond, Þat was trew and kynde; And when he had do þus, ywys, With his brother, sir Amys, A?en þen gan he wende. In muche ioy with-out stryf To-geder ladde þey her lyf, Tel god after hem dide sende. Anoon þe hend barons tway, Þey let reyse a feire abbay And feffet it ry?t wel þoo, In Lumbardy, in þat contray, To senge for hem tyl domesday And for her eldres also. Boþ on oo day were þey dede And in oo graue were þey leide, Þe kny?tes boþ twoo; And for her trewþ and her godhede Þe blisse of heuyn þey haue to mede, Þat lasteþ euer moo. Amen.
